asset.nameText: Sequencing technology at the Sanger Centre, Cambridge.

subpages.title: Sequenced at the Sanger Centre
content: Mike and his team had a secret weapon – the human genome project. The Sanger Centre was ready to embark on sequencing the human genome for the first time. Mike was able to collaborate so that the DNA of chromosome 13 - the location where Mike’s team suspected BRCA2 lay – was the first million letters of DNA to be sequenced.

contents.title: The search for the BRCA2 gene

subpages.title: The search for the BRCA2 gene [introduction]
content: BRCA1 and 2 testing are some of the most prevalently used genetic tests in the world. Today hundreds of thousands, if not millions of [men and ?] women have been tested for the presence of a BRCA2 mutation.
Consequences can pose difficult choices from preventative surgery to remove breasts and ovaries or a lifetime of frequent screening.

subpages.title: The team that tracked BRCA2 down
content: Professor Stratton and his team revealed the identity of BRCA2 in a paper published in the journal Nature at the end of 1995.
Mike explains the significance of BRCA2:
[Audio clip]

asset.nameText: Understanding the presence of disease across a family is essential to create genetic family tree-known as a pedigree

subpages.title: A family history of breast cancer
content: The team began to research large family trees where there was a history of cancer. The researchers analysed DNA from 15 families from around the world affected by early-onset breast cancer that wasn’t related to BRCA1.
“Over the period of about 18 months this huge family tree was put together with hundreds of people on the tree…very tellingly we then found an individual with male breast cancer”.

That was an important observation because male breast cancer did not seem to be a feature of BRCA1 based susceptibility to breast cancer and that added weight to the notion that this was a different gene. The team never met the family.

asset.nameText: Ideogram of human chromosome. Chromosome 13 highlighted where the alterations can be found for BRCA2.
asset.sourceText: National Center for Biotechnology Information, U.S. National Library of Medicine

subpages.title: Finding the gene
content: Using painstaking genetic techniques, the researchers pinpointed the location of BRCA2 to a region on one end of human chromosome 13 – a region known to contain a number of different genes.
[Audio clip]

subpages.title: A race to the gene
content: Mike’s team wasn’t alone in looking to identify the BRCA2 gene. An American company called Myriad Genetics had been successful in isolating BRCA1 with the aim to provide tests for BRCA1. However, what was a cause of concern for Mike and other researchers was that the company had taken out patents essentially monopolising the usage of BRCA1.  They were looking to do the same with BRCA2.
“ DNA is in all of us, it belongs to humanity, …so what had previously been a collaboration to find the position of BRCA2 now became a competition and it became a race to actually identify the gene.”

asset.nameText: Patient blood test taken for genetic screening.

subpages.title: The first patient to be tested for BRACA2
content: Mike recalls how quickly the gene’s identification impacted potential patients.
[Audio clip]

subpages.title: Title Page
content: Has he lost his mind?
Can he see or is he blind?
Can he walk at all,
Or if he moves will he fall?
Is he alive or dead?
Has he thoughts within his head?
We'll just pass him there
Why should we even care?

subpages.title: Hotspot Tag 1
content: He was turned to steel
In the great magnetic field
Where he traveled time
For the future of mankind

subpages.title: Hotspot Tag 2
content: Nobody wants him
He just stares at the world
Planning his vengeance
That he will soon unfold

asset.developer_comments: Model is approx x: -10, 10 y: 36, -36 z: -5, 5

subpages.title: Self-Conscious Gene by Marc Quinn
content: Quinn’s sculpture portrays Rick Genest, an actor, artist and model from Canada, known for covering his entire body in anatomical tattoos.
Explore the artwork in detail to find out more about Rick’s life, how the statue was made, and the history of tattooing.

subpages.title: Working with Bronze
content: Made of bronze, this statue was cast in sections and then welded together.
These lines show the joining points and have been left to reveal the making process.
The surface of bronze changes colour, which will change the appearance of these joins over time.

subpages.title: Brain Surgery
content: Rick developed a brain tumour in his early teens. After successful surgery he began to have anatomical imagery tattooed on to his body.
His head shows a visible brain above a distinct line, as if the skull and scalp have been lifted off.

subpages.title: Full-body tattoos
content: Although you can’t see them, Rick’s legs were also covered in tattoos. Full ‘bodysuit’ tattoos have been common in Japan for centuries but were only adopted in Europe and America from the early 1900s.

subpages.title: A Towering Presence
content: Standing next to Quinn’s sculpture, adult visitors appear to shrink to the size of a toddler. The head is made larger, the legs narrower to emphasise Rick’s monumental presence.
Please feel free to hold his hand and become part of the scene.

subpages.title: Skull and Cross bones
content: The tattooed zombie head was Rick’s first tattoo. Zombies were a popular choice of image in 1990s tattooing. Rick’s tattoos often drew on imagery from horror films.
He was later nicknamed Zombie Boy.

subpages.title: Tattooed insects
content: Rick’s tattoos combine anatomy and horror film imagery to produce the effect of a decomposing corpse. Spot the maggots, centipedes and other bugs all over his body.
Animals are popular tattoo subjects in many cultures with a range of symbolic meanings.

subpages.title: Knuckle tattoos
content: Rick had the words ‘Evil’ and ‘Dead’ tattooed across his knuckles.

This is a common tattoo design, made famous by the American film Night of the Hunter in 1955, where a character has ‘Love’ and ‘Hate’ on his knuckles. Tattoos often reflect fundamental human emotions.

subpages.title: Famous anatomical imagery
content: Open in Rick’s hands is an anatomy book featuring famous images on the cover. These featured in the book ‘On the Fabric of the Human Body’ by Andreas Vesalius in 1543. The back uses a popular European emblem of a skeleton reflecting on death.
See a copy of the book elsewhere in this gallery.

subpages.title: Biohazard
content: Rick chose to feature a large biohazard symbol in the centre of his chest. Images of chemical waste also appear on his upper arms. This forms part of his overall imagery as a rotting corpse.
This tattooed symbol was also adopted by gay men with HIV in the 1990s.

subpages.title: Layered tattoos
content: You can clearly see Rick’s spine tattooed down the centre of his back, but it lies over other older tattoos.
It is common to build up tattoos in layers as people’s tastes and identities change over time. Rick started with more traditional image choices and added the anatomy over the top.

subpages.title: Spiders’ webs
content: Both of Rick’s elbows were tattooed with cobwebs. These link to the insects visible all over his body, feeding on his larger imagery as a ‘decomposing corpse’. Cobwebs have been a common tattoo choice since the 1950s.

subpages.title: Muscular Corset
content: These muscles on Rick’s lower back are part of the anatomical imagery tattooed all over his body.
A popular theme of 1990s tattooing featured ‘skin rips’ that appeared to show the body under a person’s skin, sometimes muscle, sometimes machine.
In art history this is called an écorché, a painting or sculpture of a human figure with the skin removed to display the muscles.

subpages.title: Barbed wire
content: Tattooed barbed wire covers Rick, giving the sense that his body is bursting against these constraints.
Barbed wire comes in and out of fashion as a tattoo, it was very popular in the 1990s and again in the late 2010s.

subpages.title: Memento Mori
content: Many of Rick’s tattoos used imagery of death and dying, like these gravestones. Called memento mori, these are a popular image in Western art used to remind viewers of the fragility of life. They have also been part of tattoo history since the tattoos chosen by Christian pilgrims in the 1600s.
